metadata.case_name: Appellant (Elector of Rohru Constituency) v. Sri Padam Dev

facts.text: On 12th October 1951, five candidates (respondents 1 to 5) were duly nominated for election to the Legislative Assembly of Himachal Pradesh for Rohru Constituency in Mahasu District.
On 30th November 1951, first respondent (Sri Padam Dev) declared elected having secured largest number of votes; result published in Official Gazette on 20th December 1951.
On 14th February 1952, Gyan Singh (fifth respondent, unsuccessful candidate) filed Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 challenging validity of first respondent's election.
On 4th August 1952, Gyan Singh applied to withdraw petition; permitted by Tribunal order dated 20th September 1952.
Appellant (elector in Rohru Constituency) applied to be brought on record as petitioner; ordered on 21st November 1952.
Daulataram (Government servant in post office) subscribed as proposer, Motiram (Government servant in post office) as seconder in nomination paper of Sri Padam Dev.
Sital Singh (extra-departmental agent, Government servant) appointed by Sri Padam Dev as polling agent at booth at Arhal.

Sri Padam Dev had contracts for supply of Ayurvedic medicines to Himachal Pradesh Government: Mandi contract (goods supplied, price received September 1951); Mahasu contract (order 19th November 1951, goods December 1951-January 1952); Sirmur contract (order 25th September 1951, goods supplied 1st December 1951; letters/telegram 31st October, 27th/30th November 1951).

Election Tribunal by judgment dated 23rd May 1953 (noted as 25th September 1953) held: s.7(d) Act XLIII 1951 not applicable to Part C States; no proof of subsisting contracts on 12th October 1951; s.123(8) not prohibiting proposing/seconding; point on Sital Singh not raised in petition. Petition dismissed.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 25th January 1954.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sri Padam Dev disqualified under s.7(d) Act XLIII of 1951 (contracts with Government) via s.17 Act XLIX of 1951 and Art.102(1)(e) Constitution for Part C States election.
Whether contracts subsisting with appropriate Government at material date(s).
Whether procuring assistance of Government servants (proposer/seconder Daulataram/Motiram; polling agent Sital Singh) contravened s.123(8) Act XLIII of 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.7(d) Act XLIII 1951 applies via s.17 Act XLIX 1951 incorporating Art.102(1)(e) Constitution to Part C States; contracts with Himachal Pradesh Government are with Central Government via Art.239/77; subsisting on material dates including up to Gazette publication.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Act XLIII 1951 s.7(d), s.9(1)(a); Act XLIX 1951 s.17; Constitution Art.102(1)(e), 239, 77

petitioner_arguments.text: Govt servants Daulataram/Motiram subscribing nomination, Sital Singh as polling agent procured assistance contravening s.123(8).
Tribunal erred on subsisting contract law (delivery does not end if price due); material period nomination to Gazette publication; acceptance in Oct/Nov 1951 for Sirmur contract.

respondent_arguments.text: Act XLIII 1951 not proprio vigore applicable to Part C States; s.17 Act XLIX excludes s.7(d) as Part II not extended by s.8; contracts with State not Central Govt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Act XLIX 1951 s.8, s.17; Act XLIII 1951 s.7(d)

respondent_arguments.text: No subsisting contracts on nomination date 12 Oct 1951; goods supplied post-nomination.
S.123(8) does not prohibit Govt servants proposing/seconding (privilege under s.33(2)); polling agent appointment not per se violation.

court_reasoning.text: S.17 Act XLIX incorporates disqualifications under Art.102(1)(e) including s.7(d) Act XLIII; omission of Part II in s.8 does not exclude as s.17/7 cover qualifications/disqualifications; no inconsistency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: What disqualifies for Parliament under Act of Parliament disqualifies for State Assembly.

court_reasoning.text: Contracts with Part C State (via Chief Commissioner) not with Central Government (Art.239 distinct; s.38(2) Act XLIX); no proof of Central Govt contracts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Part C States not merged with Central Govt.

court_reasoning.text: No subsisting contracts on nomination date (admitted material date); Tribunal errors on law immaterial as facts show no contracts then; cannot change case on appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant bound by concession on material date.

court_reasoning.text: S.123(8) does not prohibit Govt servant proposing/seconding (s.33(2) privilege); polling agent appointment per se not violation (s.46, Rule 12, Form 6; duties do not aid prospects without more); no specific plea; no abuse proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere appointment without exploitation not infringement.

holdings.text: S.7(d) Act XLIII applies to Part C States via s.17 Act XLIX but requires contract with Central Govt for Parliament disqualification; State contracts do not disqualify.
No subsisting contracts proved at material date.
Appointment of Govt servant as proposer/seconder/polling agent not per se contravention of s.123(8) absent furtherance of prospects.

precedents_cited.relevance: Contract subsists if price due post-delivery; disqualification from nomination to declaration/publication.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo
precedents_cited.relevance: S.33(2) confers privilege on electors including Govt servants to propose/second; s.123(8) does not take away.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act XLIII of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualifications for contracts; corrupt practice of govt servant assistance; applied with interpretation for Part C States.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951 (Act XLIX of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs Part C States elections; incorporates Parliament disqualifications; extends parts of Act XLIII.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Parliament disqualifications apply; Part C States administration by President via Chief Commissioner, distinct from Central Govt.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People (Conduct of Elections and Election Petitions) Rules, 1951

outcome.summary: The appeal against dismissal of Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 is dismissed. No disqualification under s.7(d) as contracts not with Central Government and not subsisting; no contravention of s.123(8) by govt servants' roles. Election of Sri Padam Dev upheld.

key_quotes.text: "What would be a disqualification for a candidate being chosen to either House would be a disqualification to be chosen to the State Legislature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets s.17 Act XLIX incorporating Art.102.

key_quotes.text: "The mere appointment of a Government servant as a polling agent is in itself and without more an infringement of section 123(8). Our answer is in the negative."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds polling agent appointment per se not corrupt practice.

key_quotes.text: "section 33(2) conferred the privilege of proposing or seconding a candidate on any person who was registered in the electoral roll, and that section 123(8) could not be construed as taking away that privilege."
key_quotes.speaker: court
